Compliance is a key component of banks’ second line of defense for managing risks. Banks need to improve compliance frameworks in three main areas: governance, resources and the implementation of policies and processes. Read the full article https://t.co/EVTJthco5J https://t.co/iOM0qAWnaC

A busy day in Dublin yesterday for Executive Board member Philip R. Lane. He met students at @tcddublin and took part in a public discourse at the Royal Irish Academy, answering questions on ECB monetary policy as well as the effects of climate change on the economy. https://t.co/PIWlrInKNP

With the transition period under way, banks must accelerate and complete the implementation of their post-Brexit target operating models. Hier nochmal der richtige Link zur Präsentation https://t.co/dliJ95hiSL
Here is the correct link to the slides (in German only) https://t.co/dliJ95hiSL

Wir begrüßen eine offene Debatte über die EZB Politik und zur Überprüfung der geldpolitischen Strategie, sagt Schnabel. Diese muss jedoch auf Basis von Fakten stattfinden, nicht von Narrativen, die einer sachlichen Grundlage entbehren. 

Slides https://t.co/c3iNIGHhEm
(7/7)

Die EZB sorgt für Immobilienblasen: Trotz steigender Immobilienpreise – vor allem in Großstädten – bleiben Hauspreise in Deutschland vergleichbar niedrig. Diese sind in Deutschland fast auf gleichem Niveau wie in 1990. (6/7) https://t.co/DdnEoNQCyl

Sparer werden enteignet: Deutsche sind Kreditnehmer, Steuerzahler, Immobilienbesitzer und Arbeitnehmer – nicht nur Sparer! Günstige Kredite machen geringere Zinseinkommen auf Spareinlagen wett. Niedrige Zinsen auf Staatsschulden führen zu zusätzlichen Ersparnissen. (5/7) https://t.co/sWGS2eVVRG

Derzeitige Zinserträge sind untypisch: Negative Realzinsen – also Zinserträge abzüglich der Inflation – sind nichts Neues. Tatsächlich bekommen Sparer seit 45 Jahren meist keine positiven Realzinsen. (4/7) https://t.co/qLl5v4GtNt

Inflation ist zu hoch: Die Inflation im Euroraum und in Deutschland ist deutlich niedriger als vor der Einführung des Euros. Die Inflationsrate für den gesamten Euroraum seit 1999 beträgt 1,7%; in Deutschland 1,4%. (2/7) https://t.co/5lIsdnip3d

[THREAD] Die öffentliche Diskussion über die Geldpolitik hat sich in Deutschland verschärft. Direktoriumsmitglied Isabel Schnabel beleuchtet vorherrschende Narrativen und diskutiert diese auf Basis von Fakten. 
Rede https://t.co/OtshhEaBEM
Slides https://t.co/c3iNIGHhEm
(1/7) https://t.co/tY3BxM8Odh

We welcome public discussion about the ECB’s policies and its strategy review, says Schnabel. But please draw on facts rather than on narratives with no solid grounds. Read the full speech https://t.co/YOPwFZoI6S
Slides in German https://t.co/c3iNIGYSvU  (7/7)

The ECB creates real estate bubbles: Despite their recent rise, especially in large cities, German house prices remain relatively low. Nationally they are at almost the same level as in 1990. (6/7) https://t.co/wweYnjCafq

Savers are losing out: Germans are borrowers, taxpayers, house builders and workers – not just savers. Cheaper loans make up for lower interest income on saving accounts. And lower rates on government debt result in additional savings. Germans benefit from that. (5/7) https://t.co/BSmFzUJhvj

Current return on savings are atypical: Negative real interest rates – that is, interest rates after inflation has been taken into account – are nothing new. Actually, savings accounts in Germany have seen negative real interest rates for most of the past 45 years. (4/7) https://t.co/YiF7bkfPjn

Interest rates are needlessly low: Our economies don’t grow as quickly anymore. This is reflected in lower productivity growth. In addition, the working-age population has been declining for some time. (3/7) https://t.co/msOHYH1fbn

Inflation is too high: Inflation in the euro area and in Germany has in fact been significantly lower since the euro was introduced. The inflation rate for the euro area as a whole since 1999: 1.7. The rate for Germany: 1.4%. (2/7) https://t.co/XRUhforrGE

[THREAD] The public debate about monetary policy has become more heated in Germany. Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel takes a closer look at some of the dominant narratives and discusses them in the light of the facts. (1/7) https://t.co/YOPwFZ77fk https://t.co/NdhTmYfdL5

Lagarde: A more resilient EMU with these elements would help to protect our living standards from adverse domestic and global developments and support Europe’s influence in the world, including by making the euro more attractive worldwide 8/8 https://t.co/WBXcNI6cHt

Lagarde: But the completion of Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) should not be forgotten. I mean an EMU with a full banking union, underpinned by a common deposit insurance scheme; a true capital markets union; and a central stabilisation function. 7/8

Lagarde: Digitalisation and climate change affect us all and Europe is uniquely positioned to master these challenges. Building on common safeguards and competitive incentives, the Single Market offers enormous potential for economic modernisation. 6/8

Lagarde: We also have to gear up on climate change – and not only because we care as citizens of this world. Climate change affects the context in which central banks operate so we increasingly need to take these effects into account in central banks’ policies and operations. 5/8

Lagarde: The ECB is assessing the potential and implications of technological developments for payment services and financial stability, such as whether a central bank digital currency could serve a clear purpose for the public and support the ECB’s objectives. 4/8
Lagarde: Digitalisation and climate change are global phenomena. They will not wait for us to gear up and get ready; they will affect us whether we are ready or not. We need to prepare. 3/8
Lagarde: Independence and accountability are two sides of the same coin; one cannot exist without the other. This is why the ECB’s relationship with the @Europarl_EN is so important. 2/8

(THREAD) President @Lagarde spoke today about the structural challenges affecting the euro area economy during the @Europarl_EN plenary session on the ECB Annual Report 2018. Read the full speech https://t.co/WBXcNI6cHt 1/8

Lagarde: We aim to learn directly from civil society and the people what matters most to them – be that rising rents and house prices, job uncertainty or climate change – and to assess how we can best take those concerns into account, within the limits of our mandate.

Lagarde: We will be keen to hear the views of a wide range of stakeholders, including academics, financial sector representatives, students and civil society organisations. Our first such listening ECB event will take place in Brussels in late March.
Lagarde: As part of the review, we will launch a new series of listening events. We will run these across the entire euro area, together with colleagues from the national central banks.

Lagarde: It is the everyday economic decisions of people and companies that we seek to influence with our policy and communication. If our language is not accessible, if we are not open and clear, our policy will be less effective.

Lagarde: Traditionally, as central bankers we have been more comfortable speaking to experts and markets than to the general public. Markets closely follow what we do and what we say, and surveys and studies find that we are well understood by them.
Lagarde: Good communication forms the bedrock of the ECB’s credibility and underpins our legitimacy in the eyes of the people we serve.

Lagarde: We know that people will only come to trust us more and see the ECB as their central bank, if they better understand our decisions, why they matter, and what impact they have on people’s day-to-day lives. That is why the review will look at how we communicate our policy.

ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos says banks can improve their profitability and resilience by diversifying sources of income and improving cost efficiency. He also calls for a macroprudential framework for non-banks https://t.co/WHQwHA9NXg https://t.co/RokpYEURyf

Lagarde: In the light of these changes, now is the appropriate time for us to conduct a strategy review with a broad scope to ensure we continue to deliver on our mandate in the best interest of Europeans.
Lagarde: Since the ECB last reviewed its strategy in 2003, the world economy has undergone profound structural changes that have transformed the environment in which monetary policy operates.
Introductory statement Christine Lagarde at a hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/9McDcejPxF

Coming up in 15 mins: ECB President Christine @Lagarde’s quarterly hearing before the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs @EP_Economics.

Follow live from 09:00 https://t.co/JPegf71S0M https://t.co/EdI00szbFr

Lagarde on moving forward: We can master the shifting business environment. Our attitude must be one of cooperation without compromise, open to the world but protective of our values. We must work together as policymakers, businesses and Europeans 4/4 https://t.co/UulMAZbBbu

Lagarde on climate risks: We need to extend our knowledge of the macroeconomic effects of climate change. Climate risks must also be properly reflected so that the public and private sectors can take them into account more systematically 3/4

Lagarde on European autonomy: Deep and liquid financial markets are needed to boost the euro’s global role and this requires a genuine capital markets union. The ECB can contribute by providing innovative market infrastructures and being an accelerator in payment solutions 2/4

Lane on the ECB’s strategy review: Let me draw a clear line between the strategy review and any near/medium-term policymaking. The strategy review is about what is the best approach. It should not be read as having any link back to today’s policymaking. https://t.co/TGYvqz9thO

Lane on central bank proactivity: If you are indifferent, if you ignore the importance of getting inflation up over time, then you can get locked into a kind of low inflation trap. That, we think, would be quite dangerous.
Lane on correcting inflation: Getting inflation back to target from below is something where the playbook is quite different to getting inflation back to target from above.
Executive Board member Philip R. Lane discussed the factors behind global inflation in an interview with the Financial Times. Read more https://t.co/TGYvqz9thO https://t.co/bmTVFbch9v

German Federal President Steinmeier today awarded former ECB President Mario Draghi the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany in a ceremony in Berlin. This is the highest award given to individuals for services to the country. https://t.co/Ne8S9PvscS
In the second part of the interview with Trade Finance Global Yves Mersch discusses central bank independence and monetary and supervisory policy issues https://t.co/E0kPCPIGwp

The national central banks of all EU member states each have a share in the ECB’s capital. Together, they own the ECB. How are these shares calculated? And when do they change? Find out in our new explainer https://t.co/tQGTN4mipJ https://t.co/VqQ7vqAYKr

Following #Brexit, the ECB’s capital will remain steady at €10.8 billion. The Bank of England’s contributions will be repaid and its share of the ECB’s capital will be reallocated among euro-area and non-euro area national central banks. More details https://t.co/h6I8d1tWwZ
